title: Does rap count as music? - Quora

response.answer_text: They talk instead of singing.- Yeah, they do. Leonard Cohen talks all over all of his songs, but he is still called one of the greatest songwriters of the Rock and Roll era. Calling what Lou Reed(RIP) did singing is a stretch, but he is regarded as one of the most influential voices of his generation. Sprechstimme, the singsong type of speech singing used in such great canonical works as Berg's Wozzeck, is merely the use of the natural tonal properties in speech as a musical instrument. Rap is music.They don't even speak properly- Proper according to whom? Rap is a product of urban blight, poverty and the necessity to express, that is informed by bleeding-edge slang, up-to-the-minute fashion, and current events in the inner city (this is how rap started...I'm not saying that it is this now...it's grown beyond these parameters) When jazz was the popular music in America, it too was derided for not being musical. Now, it is revered, and rightly so. Both of these musics are the products of Black Americans. I'm beginning to see a pattern...are you? There is no melody- I don't know what "established music norms" you are referring to, but in my study of music, Arnold Schoenberg, John Cage, the aforementioned Berg, and Charles Ives made it a point to write music that did away with the conventional concept of tonal center. These composers did this 70+ years ago. Any set of "Music Norms" needs to take into account these pioneers of 20th Century compostion, which make this point quite moot. They use 3rd grade rhyming schemes- I suggest you listen to some early Eminem, anything by Rakim, Public Enemy, and especially Aesop Rock if you want internal rhyme, extended metaphor and the like. Simple rhyme schemes have their place, especially in early rap by the likes of Run-DMC, the Trecherous Three, and Grandmaster Flash, when the artform was in it's infancy. When the main reason to rhyme was to exhort others to join in the celebration, simple worked better than complex. Nowadays, rap has expanded to include personal expression, and grand storytelling, so you're going to find the complete range of rhyming from Chief Keef's embarrassingly simple couplets to Brother Ali's fully-formed tales of opression and triumph. Open your ears, and listen. You might be surprised. They use words to rhyme , but not to complete a thought- Again, you need to expand your hip-hop listening. One of the most valued skills in battle rhyming is the ability to set up and complete a punchline. Punchlines not only have a fun rhyme scheme, they also lead you along, like a good comedian, and then POW! the last line blows up all over the other rapper, hopefully to face-covering approval by the audience. Completeing the thought, forcefully, is a mark of an accomplished MC. The "Music" is on an eight-second loop- Again, I'm going to suggest some listening. Timbaland, El-P, Pharrell...these guys make high-concept, very complex and highly listenable music. What's more, is there are many changes, rhythmic, melodic and otherwise, that keep the interest of the listener. People wonder why these guys make the money they do. It's because when they make a track, people dance. I've tried to do it, and it may be the hardest artistic thing to do outside of stand-up comedy. They don't play instruments- OK, the vast majority of them don't. But the Beastie Boys did, to great effect. As do The Roots. I have to say also, that this question takes a very narrow view of music. Hip-hop has been the most popular form of music around the world (questionably) and in the US for sure. I hope that you can expand you're experience. I'm not saying that you'll love it, but you should respect it as an American art form.

I can't believe it's taken me this long to post a comment, but after several years of enjoying all of the great insights and perspectives from the Quora community, I absolutely MUST chime in on this question.  With nothing but respect for other people's musical inclinations, I humbly, but strongly, disagree with your take on this. In an effort to not make this a mere rant, I won't get into all of the intricate details of why hip-hop, or rap, for me, is the greatest form of musical expression and creativity in the world...which in my opinion, it is. I'd rather just make a quick statement and then provide you with a list of artists who truly embody this form of art.  Hip-hop, in its roots, was forged out of struggle. Much like the blues, it's an expression of the realities of life for (the most-part) an underground society.Or, stated another way, the mainstream garbage you hear on the radio that espouses (mostly) materialistic escapism, has NOTHING to do with real hip-hop...and I'm guessing this is what you're basing your opinion of it on. REAL hip-hop is, and forever will be of, by, and for the underground. Wu-Tang Clan is probably the best example (for most people) of grimey boom-bap seeing commercial mainstream success. But what the Wu did was shed just a little bit of light on the unbelievable amount of talent that exists within the underground. So rather than listening to me go on and on about why REAL hip-hop is so great (because I could), here's some artists I highly encourage you and any other musical enthusiast to check out: Jedi Mind Tricks (Philly, PA)Army of the Pharaohs (East Coast US)Immortal Technique (Harlem, NY)Rhyme Asylum (London, UK)Wu-Tang Clan...specifically GZA & Method Man (New York)Gang Starr (New York)...RIP GURUDilated Peoples (Los Angeles, CA)LowKey (London, UK)Swollen Members (Vancouver, B.C., Canada)Living Legends (Los Angeles/Bay Area, CA)Heiroglyphics (Bay Area, CA)The Pharcyde (Los Angeles, CA)Sean Price (Brooklyn, NY)Jurassic 5 (Los Angeles, CA)Atmosphere (Minneapolis, MN)Brother Ali (Minneapolis, MN)The Left (Detroit, MI)Zion I (Bay Area, CA)Cali Agents (Bay Area, CA)Aesop Rock (New York/Los Angeles)Cannibal Ox (New York)El Da Sensei (New Jersey)EPMD (New York)R.A. The Rugged Man (New York)Eric B. & Rakim (New York)Roc Marciano (New York)Scarface (Houston, TX)The Roots (Philly, PA)The Alkaholiks (Los Angeles, CA)Snow Goons (Germany) I left out quite a bit, particularly the early pioneers like Public Enemy, Run-DMC, Fab 5 Freddy, Kool G Rap, Big Daddy Kane, etc...nothing but respect for the forefathers of the genre...but any real hip-hop fan out there who can resonate with this list, please feel free to chime in.  And, yes, I realize I left out the heavy hitters like Jay-Z, 2Pac, Notorious B.I.G., Ice Cube, Dr. Dre, NWA, Eminem, Snoop Dogg, etc...All talented artists, all contributed immensely to the industry...but not, in my opinion, the defining artists of the genre as many prop them up to be.  And yes, I realize I didn't mention the likes of Kanye West, Drake, Lil' Wayne, and some of the other dregs of hip-hop's corporate puppets (please refer to the "mainstream garbage" reference from earlier. Real hip-hop is an unadulterated expression and commentary of (among other things) struggle, progress, perseverance, wisdom, social injustice, love, hate, raw, grimey, boom-bap passion. Born in the U.S....now very well represented internationally. The hip-hop underground will continue to thrive, as long as it remains underground.  That's all I got. Peace and love.

Your list of points suggests you haven’t listened to much hip-hop, only the very narrow subgenre of mainstream hip-hop you’d hear on the radio. You’re also confusing rapping, a vocal style, with hip-hop, a genre of music. I’m going to put the points I think needed addressing the most first, so don’t be confused by the numbers jumping around: 7. They don't even play the instruments. Most pop artists don’t play instruments, does this mean the instrumental backing to their tracks is not music? Of course not. Same for the fact most rappers don’t play instruments, it doesn’t mean the instrumental backing to their tracks is no longer music. Here’s a video of the Beastie Boys playing their instruments while rapping (they started out as a punk band before branching out into hip-hop and eventually funk) does the fact Adrock is rapping make the music they’re playing on their instruments no longer music?  4. They use 3rd grade rhyming schemes. If you were writing rhymes like this a third grader you were some kind of child prodigy: “Palestine, Kosovo, Kashmir / No different than the avenues right here / An increase in the murder rate each year / Paramilitary unit keep the streets clear / Curtains up on the theatre of warfare / Dramatic politics nightly perform here / Worldwide from Columbia to Coumbine / Stockholders keep the dollar signs underlined.” “Penitentiary chances / The devil dances and eventually answers / To the call of Autumn / All them fallen / For the love of balling / Get caught with 30 rocks the cop look like Alec Baldwin.” 1. They talk instead of singing. Wrong. They don’t talk, they rap. Sometimes singing is involved too, for example Yasiin Bey aka Mos Def frequently combines singing and rapping in his songs. >2. They don't even speak properly. That’s because they’re rapping. Unless you’re referencing rappers who use certain slang or have regional accents, in which case that’s obviously not true. 3. There is no melody. Now it’s starting to just sound like you haven’t listened to any hip-hop before. 5. They use words to rhyme but not that complete a thought Not inherent or unique to hip-hop, just a sign of bad song writing. 6. The "music" is on an 8 second loop Another thing that isn’t inherent or unique to hip-hop. This is just bad songwriting. Unless you’re referring to beats making use of loops, which would of course be incorrect due to beat changes.

Dear White People (I have always wanted to start a Quora answer this way), Greetings. I am at least as white as many of you. I am a professional opera singer; can you think of a whiter profession than that? If so, please let me know, and I’m sure I could dabble in it. I’m here, as a subject expert in “established norms in music,” to tell you that rap is music. It’s sort of astonishing to me that I even need to say this, but after reading many comments on Habib Fanny’s absolutely wonderful answer, it’s come to my attention that many of you disagree with the objective fucking truth: that rap is music. To borrow from the lyrics of a great musician: “Now I ain’t sayin’ she a [closet racist], but she ain’t messin’ with no [traditionally white genres of music].” The standard critique of rap as music is that it lacks melody. Cool. Please sing for me the melody of the most famous section of Stravinsky’s famous The Rite of Spring, called the Augurs of Spring (audio below, if you don’t know what I’m talking about). Can’t do it? I didn’t think so. Whole genres of music are built without melody. Would you consider minimalist music not to be music? How about percussion music? And even on traditionally pitched/melodic instruments; think about the way solo banjo is played, or bagpipe music. Is anyone asking on Quora whether bagpipes count as music? (BTW, for those of you considering a cheapshot in the comments against bagpipes, that’s fair, but actually high-level bagpipe music is really cool).  (The Augurs of Spring) “It’s not that it lacks melody,” I hear you say, “it’s that it lacks pitch and tone!” In the examples I give, those are all pitched instruments. Funny you should say this, because human voices rapping also have pitch and timbre. Have you ever considered why we can tell the difference between DMX rapping and Jay Z? The difference is far more extreme than the difference between a bassoon and an oboe—it’s not just pitch and expression, it’s a huge timbral shift. I’ve also heard the argument that it’s not about what’s embedded in rap, it’s about what rap is famous for: the fact that people like rap overwhelmingly for its use of text makes it not music. Cool. So does Bob Dylan still count as music, even though his music is almost 100% about text? The bottom line is that none of the arguments against rap as music are applied with any consistency. The same people who wish to categorize rap as something other than music due to these qualities ignore the same qualities in other, traditionally white, genres. In point of fact, rap is often the most sophisticated pop music around. Think about the way sampling is done in rap and compare it to borrowings in Handel, or to 20th century tape music. Rap has an extremely sophisticated musical lineage and heightens it in ways that huge numbers of high-level musicians find compelling. So this has been a fun little conversation that we’ve been having, but it’s time to stop. Rap is music. Often very high-level music. I appreciate that this issue gets a whole new segment of the population interested in becoming armchair music theorists, but this argument is totally racist nonsense. Love, always, David

Yes, rap, rap music or rapping is music and as a part of music, it is art. A lot of various people are defying rap as not a part of it due to their lack of musical knowledge or just due to their subjective opinion.  1. The first thesis is partly correct, but, rapping or rap is a genre of music which is not based on singing or showing how high or pitched your voice can be, instead, it is based on your flow (how do you pronounce your rhymes, at what tempo, can you or cannot control your breath, how long can your verse be etc.) and on your delivery (how your rhymes will be ''delivered'' to the audience, or better, to the microphone - for instance, will you stress some to you important syllable or even a line). Also, it is important how do you feel the beat. A good rapper should know how to be in a perfect symbiosis with a beat, even though nowadays there are more and more good off beat rappers.  2. You are probably referring to mostly black rappers who've invented a whole new slang so they could understand among each other and differ from other subcultures. And this is the main reason (language) why hip-hop is a subculture.  3. Actually, there is. I assume you mean that there is no melody in their voices. Well, many rappers have monotonous voice in their delivery, but, you can find many rappers that sound better than most of mainstream pop singers. I am going to take an example of Andre 3000 who has a great melody in his voice, and also Big L who has a great nasal voice.  4. This is definitely not true since one of the most important things for a rapper is an intelligent verse. This statement probably comes from a person who never heard of any other rapper than Jay Z, Eminem, Snoop Dogg and other mainstream rappers, so I'll take it for granted. There is a sea of rappers with high intelligent verses like Aesop Rock, RiFF RAFF, Action Bronson, Nas, Wu Tang etc. who had more words in their art than Shakespeare in his. But, it's not only important to use many various words, it is important to gather them into song that makes sense - like Aesop Rock does. His lyrics are full of metaphors, allegories, puns and wordplays that you can't understand what is he talking about even after listening to the song for 20 times. His lyrics are usually about rap/music corruption, life themes, death, philosophy, money and its effects, and he has a lot of to talk about since he had several nerve breakdowns. Rappers are better lyricists than rockers or metalheads, not only because they've invented a whole art from delivering written words, but because they can entertain you with their words. But also, multi-syllabic rhyming, wordplay, even famous stories (Immortal Technique - Dance with the Devil) all come from rap. So, we can say that their rhymes are at advanced levels compared to other music genres.  5. There is a thing called ''stream of consciousness''. A lot of rappers prefer this retelling technique when telling stories/anecdotes/life lessons in their songs. So, since you can't be in their skin, it is hard to accept when a rapper jumps from one point of view to another philosophy. Sometimes they don't have sense, but in most, they do. Great storytellers are the Wu-Tang, Action Bronson, Aesop Rock, GangStarr and especially NaS, which career is based on simply retelling his life as a juvenile in Queensbridge, NYC.  6. Could be, but it doesn't have to. All depends on the producers who make the beats firstly, then instrumentals. There is plenty of repeating oldschool producers like DJ Premier (he's a great producer, but his beats are exactly 8 sec loops), Dr. Dre; while there are revolutionists like RZA. New producers are even better since TRAP has been introduced (El-P, Blockhead etc.). In Croatia, there is a sea of great producers like Vojko Vrućina, TREEZ, Flowdeep, Krešo Bengalka and others who are inovative and creative.  7. Some do, some don't. Some oldschool producers created their own samples by playing on instruments. Nowadays, you have samples and loops on every corner which is little ruining rap. Some Croatian producers are also multi-instrumentalists playing often more than 5 instruments. Others make music on samplers or on computer programs (Ableton, FL Studio etc.)

Yes, rap is a genre of music.  To address the extremely silly points you raised: They talk instead of singing.Rapping isn't really talking. It emphasizes rhythm in a way that talking does not. It isn't singing, of course, but music doesn't need singing to be music. I'm sure you're aware of the existence of instrumental music. They don't even speak properly.Rappers often use a dialect of English called "African-American Vernacular English" or "Ebonics" (although I really hate that term). Lots of music involves dialects. Some rap isn't in AAVE, of course. There is no melody.Rapping is usually not melodic, but the rapping is usually accompanied by melody. They use 3rd grade rhyming schemes.Rappers use all kinds of rhyme schemes. Even if they only used very simple ones, though, that wouldn't prevent rap from being considered music. Lots of songs have very simple rhyme schemes. They use words to rhyme but not that complete a thought.Rappers choose their words for all kinds of reasons. They often tell long and interesting stories while maintaining a complex rhyme scheme. Even if they didn't give a damn about coherence, though, that wouldn't prevent rap from being considered music. Lots of songs have nonsense lyrics. The "music" is on an 8 second loop.The instrumental part of a rap song might be highly repetitive, or it might not be. Even if it is highly repetitive, though, that wouldn't prevent rap from being considered music. Lots of songs have highly repetitive instrumentation. They don't even play the instruments.Rappers usually don't play the instruments. Some of them do, though. Even if they didn't, though, who cares? Opera singers don't play instruments, either, last I checked. Really, the impression I'm getting here is that you've heard one or two party songs on the radio and have made exactly zero effort to learn about the genre before passing judgment on it. Which is a great way to look foolish.

Yes. Rap is music. Your points do not put rap outside the "established norms" of music, whatever they might be. Many of your points related to the lyrics of rap music which you claim use 3rd grade rhyming schemes, involve talking instead of singing with no melody, and use words that don't complete a thought all of which are not spoken properly. Even if all these claims were true (and they're not) it still doesn't disqualify rap from the classification "music." Mary Had a Little Lamb uses a 3rd grade rhyming scheme but it's still definitely music and it would be even if it wasn't sung "properly" . Scat singing is mainly rhyming without any thoughts at all, it's still music. All natural speech contains a melody of some kind. Natural speech cadence is melodic. As far as I'm aware there has never been a definite set of rules that a melody needs to fit into before it can be considered music. Even if rap music is on an 8 second repeated loop, and played without a single instrument (and again that's not actually true) that still doesn't mean it can't be called music. Music can be created by any means the musician dictates. It can be performed on a cello or by someone banging a cello with a carrot or by someone using the cello setting on a casio keyboard or by someone tapping the C E L and O keys on their keyboard.  You clearly don't like rap music. I don't care for it much myself. But just because you don't like something doesn't mean you can redefine the term "music" to exclude it.

A simple yet complex question. Here is my take on this: I STRONGLY DISLIKE rap. However, I also MOSTLY LISTEN to rap. Need me to explain? Of course you do, you are an average rap fan. Here it goes: The rap ‘’formula’’ is really appealing to me - you have a simple rhythm which is catchy and easy to follow, you have a great opportunity to express yourself, along with freedom to do so, and the main focus is (should be) on the lyrics, on the content of the text. There are so many songs in so many other genres which have like 2x4 lines of verses, and 2 or 3 repetitions of the chorus, which is only catchy and nothing else. I hated this in my earlier days, and that made me choose rap over other genres. However…the vast majority of rappers seem to be satisfied with being sub-par…They are scared to do any kind of experimentation…they are too dumb or high to talk about anything other then being dumb or high…They rhyme the same bleepin’ words over and over, like there isn’t an INFINITE choice of rhymes out there… What really gets me is the relationship the fans have to the rappers…In any other genres, I can truly understand the reasons why some people worship certain artists…For instance, they will say ‘’oh he’s cute’’, or ‘’I like the rhythm of the songs’’ or ‘’I like anything that has an electric guitar in it’’, etc. However, a rap fan will more often then not say something so off that you would think that there are little people in them controlling their breathing for them…Examples: ‘’I like (such and such) rapper because he is conscious.’’ And the guy is rapping about ancient conspiracies so removed from reality that he probably has assistance getting up from bed in the morning. ‘’I love (such and such) rapper because he is real.’’ And the guy talks about doing drugs in infinite amounts while simultaneously having sex with every girl you ever had…and that’s about it. ‘’I adore (such and such) rapper because he is intelligent.’’ Yet, the guy gives life advice comparable with ‘’leave school, shoot someone and rob them’’. Yeah, a real scholar. ‘’I respect his skill because he is one of the rare rappers who knows how to freestyle’’. Yet, freestyle is literally the easiest thing to do - you just list things that rhyme. Now, don’t get me wrong, I do appreciate a good, different freestyle when I hear it - but the people who can rap them are NOT the ones getting praise, but those who rhyme the super-simple nonsensical crap. (yo yo, I am in the house, I like bitches, but I am no mouse) I went on a bit of a long rant here, but I hope you get my point. Rap should be a cool thing…but rappers ruin it, and they get away with it due to a vastly unintelligent audience. :)

Instead of listening to third-grade music nowadays listen to actual, real, rap songs back in the 90s or 80s when Hip-Hop was at it’s peak. I’m gonna go ahead and prove why every point you made is completely absurd and idiotic. Rapping is classed as singing, whether you sing fast, slow, high, deep. Whatever. If it goes with a good beat and it has rhythm it can be classed as singing. Heck, it doesn’t even have to rhyme, just needs rhythm and beat and actual lyrics.Pretty sure if you researched Hip-Hop, you’d know it’s underground music, therefore a lot of people who grow up in bad neighborhoods use slang terms because that’s how they grew up.No melody? Are you - by all definitions - blind?! The beat is classed as melody. The voice is classed as melody. Rapping is all the melody you need.Again, the point I made when I started typing, listen to Hip-Hop songs back in the day - 2Pac, Notorious BIG, Nas, NWA, Big L, Slick Rick, Big Daddy Kane. Anything to get you to understand THOSE people don’t mess around. You’d drop dead thinking about how those lyrics are even possible.“Not that complete a thought” please rephrase that. If you mean they don’t give thought to their music then you’re wrong. Sure a lot of modern Hip-Hop songs aren’t very well thought out but the classic ones, especially freestyles are legendary, you’d most likely never come up with as complex rhymes as Big Daddy Kane, Biggie or Nas.How.. please tell me how. Do you mean the hook? It’s called a hook for a reason? Do you mean the beat? It’s a beat, it’s occasionally repetitive. Please get your head out of your ass and make some valid points and listen to the genre before criticising with your horrific grammar.So what if an artist doesn’t play an instrument? What, because one rapper can’t use a guitar or play the piano automatically means the genre isn’t music? A lot of artists in other genres didn’t play an instrument. What, do you think a painter isn’t a painter because they can’t paint AND be the one being painted?Please think before assuming that kind of stuff. It’s insulting. Rap/Hip-Hop is music, it has been since the late 70s and until a decade ago became a cultural phenomenon and prevented a lot things such as excessive racism being allowed, abuse against woman, sexism, police brutality and police corruption. Had you actually known that and listened to the artists I listed above you wouldn’t have typed that load of crap above. Thank you.

Per the question comments I don't think it is music, and here's why: They talk instead of singing. They don't even speak properly. There is no melody. They use 3rd grade rhyming schemes. They use words to rhyme but not that complete a thought. The "music" is on an 8 second loop They don't even play the instruments. I'm sorry but based on established norms in music these would point to rap not actually being music. What do you think? Is this music? It doesn’t even have words.  What about this? Instead of instruments, Tchaikovsky used an actual cannon.  This one has words, but it has no rhyme scheme that I can detect.  This one is moronically repetitive, but being “pop” it’s generally classed as music.  (Sorry about that one folks, had to make the point) Finally, these guys don’t use instruments.  So, by your “norms”, none of this is really music. Look, rap is music. This is pretty clearly music. It’s lyrical, it’s got a beat, and it is in fact telling a story.  Now, it’s perfectly okay if you dislike rap. I dislike rap. It just doesn’t appeal to me. There are several styles of music that just aren’t my cup of tea. I dislike most pop music too. I kinda hate elevator music.  Just because you dislike rap doesn’t make it not music. Now, not being a rap fan, I don’t know enough to go into the origin, history, development, and evolution of rap as a genre of music. But I know it’s there, and I know there are people who could explain it in exquisite detail. But I thought it might help to hear from someone who also dislikes rap. It’s still music. Even if you don’t enjoy it. Now don’t try to tell me this isn’t music too. And it’s not even human music!   Original question-Does rap count as music? Established norms in music would point to rap not actually being music.

In the US, it depends on whom you ask.  Let’s take a deeper look at the demographics. The more you approve of Trump, the more likely you are to think that rap is not music.  The older you are, the more likely you are to think that rap is not music.  If you don’t have a college degree, you’re more likely to think that rap is not music.  The more conservative you are, the more likely you are to think that rap is not music.  The less urban your neighborhood, the more likely you are to think that rap is not music.  The more you believe that federal welfare spending is too high, the more likely you are to believe that rap is not music.  What’s going on here? All these are markers associated with cultural conservatism in the US. And political identity, more often than not, is a reflection of cultural identity. Rap is associated with Blacks. Blacks are a prominent part of the American conservative out-group, to the same extent that rural Whites are a prominent part of the in-group. And people often define themselves in opposition to perceived elements associated with the out-group. For instance, I became an ardent supporter of gay marriage precisely when I started solidifying my view of conservatives as my out-group. It’s not entirely surprising that demographics groups associated with conservatism feel more antagonism to a perceived element of Black culture. You would have had the same reaction if you’d asked people about Jazz as an art form in the 1920s. That being said, although I don’t have any data to support it, I would bet that rap is more accepted as music today than it was 30 years ago. And 30 years from now, there will be even fewer people who reject it as a form of music. For more similar discussions, follow me at Sophokagathia.

Let's look at your list, shall we? I don't think it is music, and here's why: They talk instead of singing.They don't even speak properly.There is no melody.They use 3rd grade rhyming schemes.They use words to rhyme but not that complete a thought.The "music" is on an 8 second loopThey don't even play the instruments.I'm sorry but based on established norms in music these would point to rap not actually being music. What do you think? Singing is not even a prerequisite to something being music.And Bob Dylan or Dave Matthews or Jens Kidman enunciate their sung words properly? (Answer: they dont.)Drums and percussion have no melody, but they're music.And The Beatles didnt on songs like Nowhere Man?And again, The Beatles didnt on Strawberry Fields Forever?But you don't have an issue with half the songs in the world composed in the last few decades are made in the same tired as hell I-V-vi-IV chord progression?Some singers don't either, but I don't see them taking crap for not playing an instrument.What about using the definition of music instead of “established norms of music” that you made up yourself (because if we were talking about truly established norms in music, then there won't even be a debate because the norm is that rap is music). Oxford defines music as: vocal or instrumental sounds (or both) combined in such a way as to produce beauty of form, harmony, and expression of emotion. Thus: Vocal or instrumental sounds - rap has bothBeauty of form - of course, as rap is held to the same rhythmic standard as any other music, and the same writing standards as musical lyricsHarmony - of course, as it combines rhythm and words in a specific manner and styleExpression of emotion - without doubt as expressed in the choice of words, rhythm, flow, and timbreHaving checked out on all points of the objective definition of music, rap is without doubt music.

There are already a ton of great answers here, but I'd like to highlight Joseph Guthrie's answer because it does a great job of responding to each "point" you are trying to make. Instead of answering point-by-point, as many have already done so, I will say this: I encourage you to expand your horizons and listen to a wider variety of hip-hop music.  There are plenty of artists who are commonly referred to as "rappers" but who actually sing a whole lot more than they rap. Akon is a great example of such an artist. Here is a great song by him:   Akon - Freedom P.O.S. is one of my favorite underground rappers who doesn't use a lot of slang - you might find his lyrics interesting.   P.O.S. - Purexed Wale is a rapper whose music is often very instrumentally vibrant - here is one of my favorites by him.   Wale ft. Cee-Lo Green - Gullible The far-too-common condemnation of rap music as "not real music" is very annoying and always comes off to me as very racist and classist. You're minimizing the cultural contributions of rap music simply because it doesn't conform to your standards or your tastes. However, these contributions are valid and necessary - rap allows people who suffer injustices on a daily basis to vent their frustrations, demand change, or simply speak about their daily experiences. They often celebrate their success and provide inspiration for others who are struggling to get out of the hood, talk about their ambition and the hard work they put in to achieve success, and offer advice to those who are still struggling. To question whether an important cultural outlet actually "counts" as music is insulting.  Also, as a middle class white girl who has listened to rap since my pre-teen years, I can say that rap music has given me insight into the struggles of those who are less privileged than myself and helped me be more aware of the injustices that continue to exist in our "post-racial" "everyone-has-a-shot-at-success" society. So rather than listening to rap music and trying to come up with a bunch of reasons why you hate it, try listening to just one song and find the actual meaning behind it. Hear the artist's pain, listen to the message they're trying to convey, and stop comparing it to the music you prefer to listen to. Accept that it is a different type of music that usually doesn't target people such as yourself, but appreciate it as a valid and unique art form nonetheless.

Yes, it does, but not good music. I base that comment on its longevity. Rap is as disposable as any other pop pap. In a couple of years 99.99% of rap around today will be forgotten. Whereas, quality music stays around forever. That’s why we still sing Beatles songs, fifty years after they were hits. There's also a huge irony about rap. Rap is putting spoken words on top of a rhythmic backing. The words are everything. Poetry. Social comment. But in the vast majority of cases the diction of rap artists is so appallingly bad that you cannot understand a word they are saying. This is rap’s elephant in the room, the thing nobody wants to admit. The rapper ‘s new clothes. So I wonder about the validity of a musical form that claims to be all about words, but then makes those words incomprehensible. What is the point? Rappers could be reciting a phone book and you’d never know. Yes, I’m sure there are exceptions, but in general that’s how it is. And everybody knows it. Ask any teenage rap fan to tell you the words of any rap song they've been listening to, or even tell you just the gist of what those words say, and they will probably be unable to. I’ve done this. I even had one teenager tell me “But it’s not about the words! “ and then was unable to tell me what it IS all about. I suspect it’s “I listen to rap because all my friends do”. And that’s perfectly fine - pop music has always been about fitting in with your peer group. Nothing wrong with that at all. But it’s definitely not about the words. Also, with rap, the backing track is often stolen - sorry, sampled- so it’s somebody else's creativity. Plagiarism, if you like, which is always dubious. Even if the rap artist has paid royalties to use the sample, it’s still copying somebody else's work. Not creative at all. Easy. Unadventurous. Unimaginative. No, rap is not for me I’m afraid. When I want to listen to music, I don’t want it to be somebody shouting incomprehensibly at me. That’s not what I want from music.

1. They talk instead of singing. Using that logic, "Ya Got Trouble" ("right here in River City") from the Broadway musical The Music Man is not music. 2. They don't even speak properly. Using that logic, folk music forms that have existed for centuries, many of which are sung in local dialects or slang and employ the word "ain't," are not music. 3. There is no melody. Rappers often perform in certain cadences that suggest rises and falls in pitch. While that may not be considered "melody" it's certainly musical in approach. If calling it "melody" kills you, then consider it "rhythm." Still music. Is traditional African folk music that employs nothing but chants and drums not music? 4. They use 3rd grade rhyming schemes. Define what a "3rd grade rhyming scheme" is compared to the apparently more elevated 4th grade, 10th grade or even post-graduate rhyming schemes. Whether it's in grade school or college, a rhyme is pretty much a rhyme, and there's not a bunch of leeway about what makes words rhyme. They do or they don't. Furthermore, explain how Kanye West rhyming "sarcophagus" and "esophagus" is 3rd grade in nature. That's just the most obvious example, there are many others. 5. They use words to rhyme but not that complete a thought. If that were true, and it usually isn't, that would suggest all art needs a generator and a terminus of rational thought, which is ridiculous to expect from 100% of the art ever made, possibly 50% of the music. (It's not even reasonable to expect that from life.) And it would render instrumental music pointless. Stream-of-consciousness is a valid poetic and writing form; rapid-fire, stream-of-rhyme rapping is therefore valid as music. Can you explain the complete thought behind a single Jackson Pollack painting? Can you write me a three-act synopsis of John Coltrane's "A Love Supreme"? You can't; the art is the thought itself. Sometimes it gets topical, sometimes it's sexual, sometimes it's ridiculous. Every single genre of music adheres to (or is freed from) that construct. The only pieces of art that require a step-by-step narrative that begins and completes entire thoughts are how-to books. 6. The "music" is on an 8 second loop I think you mean "8-bar loop." But that's not fair either. Most pop music is built on consistent patterns that repeat throughout the song. "Surfin' Bird," "Hound Dog," the entire legacy of 12-bar blues is based on a fairly strict blueprint. I think what bothers you is that they use pre-recorded samples, but there's even an art to programming and using them. 7. They don't even play the instruments. Leaving aside that there are a bunch of hip hop artists that do play their own instruments -- watch The Tonight Show with Jimmy Fallon and you'll see one such group every single weeknight -- then anyone who just sings and doesn't play an instrument isn't music to you. "But their voice is their instrument!" you might say. But then you'd be forced to admit that rappers' voices are their instruments as well. You haven't spent enough time listening to rap. You don't have to, of course, but if you want to assess the music from any point outside of your seven rather bad ones, there's a lot of rap you can listen to to disprove them. You might have to dig deeper than the stuff you hear on the radio, but it's there. If it makes you feel any better, people have been using the same old arguments against rap as you do for about 35 years now. (See also: historical arguments against rock and jazz.) I'll defend your right not to like rap, if you defend my right not to like Kenny G. Cheers.

Music Noun Vocal or instrumental sounds (or both) combined in such a way as to produce beauty of form, harmony, and expression of emotion Above is the Oxford Dictionary definition of music. Now let’s see if the definition applies to rap. Vocal or instrumental sounds: Check; all rap has vocals in it, hence the term rapping. Most raps are over a beat which involves drums and bass. Last I checked, they are considered musical instruments. Form: Check; rap is generally structured. Many rappers use various different rhyme schemes in songs, which is what form is. Any rap song may also follow the pattern of verses and the main chorus Harmony: If you ever listen to Kanye West, you would know that he incorporates a lot of harmony into his music. West is not the only one; there are various rappers who put harmony in their songs with the instrumental background. While some rappers do not, this does not necessarily disqualify them as harmony is subjective to all people. Expression of emotion: Rapper Nas was famous for his story-telling. Eminem was also really great at story-telling but on top of that, you can hear the emotions that he spews when he raps. His songs can range from sentimental to angry to craziness and his emotions are reflected in them through the way he conveys the song.  So basically, in conclusion, rap checks off all of the criteria of being music. Many people listen to it and just because others do not like it does not mean it isn’t music. Rap is music.

Merriam-Webster defines music as: a. the science or art of ordering tones or sounds in succession, in combination, and in temporal relationships to produce a composition having unity and continuity and b. vocal, instrumental, or mechanical sounds having rhythm, melody, or harmony Vocal sounds having rhythm, melody or harmony. That sounds like rap to me. Now with the comments you made for the question, I can sense some, shall we say…biases. We can trace the origins of rap all the way to the griots of Africa (primarily western Africa) that have existed since time immemorial. A griot is the keeper or oral tradition among tribes, often accompanying music. A practice that would come with the captured Africas to America and find a place among the slave culture. This would go on to influence blues a great deal. In the 1970’s DJ Kool Herc began having “back to school” house parties in the Bronx which led to the DJ and quickly MC driven rap explosion that started in New York City. This would lead to Afrika Bambaataa and Grandmaster Flash. Then would come Run-DMC, MC Lyte, and Public Enemy, among many many others. Before long, rap moved to the west coast, and we saw the rise of the West Coast rappers like N.W.A. Ice-T and later the late greats; Tupac Shakur and The Notorious B.I.G. (I also need to say here, personal disclosure, I have everything Tupac recorded, so my opinion may be biased). The rest is history, a history that many of us are at least familiar with. Rap music is often a response to societal challenges or injustices faced by African-American communities and individuals. This is displayed by N.W.A.’s famous “Fuck da Police” which is a direct criticism of the police brutality that characterized living in Los Angeles at that time. We see similar poetry put to music through Tupac’s music, Biggie’s music, Jay-Z and many of the lesser known rappers that populate the up and coming scene. This poetry is about deeply personal things that effected them and the reality of life that many grew up with. It’s gritty at times because life was gritty. Some of the best music in the history of the world comes from places of great emotion or great obsession. Do you think that Mozart wasn’t obsessed when he wrote his symphonies? Do you not think that John Lennon wasn’t angry when he wrote Revolution (later credited to both Lennon and McCartney)? Of course they were. Don’t you think that Tupac was moved when he wrote Dear Mama? Listen to the words of that song:  You don’t think this is a man that loves his mother? You don’t think that this is a man that recognizes both his mistakes and her mistakes and acknowledges it as part of the human condition? How about Keep Ya Head Up?  In which he says: I wonder why we take from our womenWhy we rape our women, do we hate our women?I think it's time to kill for our womenTime to heal our women, be real to our womenAnd if we don't we'll have a race of babiesThat will hate the ladies, that make the babies Further on in this song Tupac laments that there is money for war, but not for feeding the poor. How can you question if this is music? Every time I hear this song it gives me goosebumps. This is a masterpiece. As socially relevant as anything the Beatles ever wrote, and as impactful as anything every produced by Aerosmith (overrated) and talks about the real world in a way that many genres of music can’t even approach. Let’s take a lightspeed jump to today’s music. Now, we can make fun of Kayne all we want. But the fact is, take all his antics away, the dude is a musical genius. I’m convinced he could write a beat with killer lyrics on pots and pans. All of the Lights:  In this song he says: “I made mistakesI bump my headCourts suck me dryI spent that breadShe need a daddyBaby please,Can't let her grow up in that ghetto university (all of the lights) “Can’t let her grow up in that ghetto university” this is about a man acknowledging mistakes and working to improve himself. He wants to provide for his daughter, and he knows he messed up when he hit his partner, that it was wrong (and domestic violence is horribly wrong) and even though her family, possibly rightly, hates him. You said in comments that the rhyme schemes are simplistic. If Tupac’s, N.W.A.’s, Kayne’s, Jay-Z’s, Nas’, or other rappers beyond count are simplistic than so is Poe. The voice can’t be an instrument? It can’t be impressive. Ha. Ha. I present Tech N9ne’s Worldwide Choppers:  Yeah, if that’s not impressive contemporary (Busta’s using stuttering here was brilliant) music, I don’t know what is. Better than the manufactured dreck being produced by Katy Perry or Nashville in general. Plus you have the fact, beyond all the lyrical meaning and expression that goes into rap; it’s catchy. Listen to some of the music I’ve linked in this answer and try not to move a little. It makes you want to move. I can’t listen to rap and not move, it makes me want to dance, or box, or other things…. (Tech’s “Caribou Lou”, I’m looking at you) Are some of the lyrics violent? Yes, they are. These men and women frequently lived in violent environments that inspired what they’re seeing. AC/DC wrote about being hitmen (“Dirty deeds done dirt cheap”) and Springsteen sang about serial killers (“Nebraska”). Are some the lyrics misogynistic? Yes, unfortunately. So is rock. Guns ’n Roses had a song “It’s so easy” whose meanings are better left undiscussed. Neil Yount wrote, “Every Man Needs a Maid”. Korn had several so much. Not to mention the general behavior of Aerosmith, GnR, and hair metal bands without number (and mainly without talent). Misogyny is a societal problem, and it is being tackled in very real ways in contemporary society. However, rock music had its female stars, Grace Slick of Jefferson Airplane/Starship, Janis Joplin. As did country in Loretta Lynn, Dolly Parton, etc. Rap and hip-hop, for all its male-dominated culture, had many female artists that were revolutionary. The aforementioned MC Lyte, Queen Latifah, Monie Love, Salt-n-Pepa, and of course the vocally powerful Lauryn Hill. Not only have women been able to participate, but they’ve been powerful people in the industry. Music makes you feel, it invokes an emotional reaction, it makes you move. Rap does all of those things, therefore, it is music. The established norms of music didn’t recognize jazz at one time, yet it had a massive part in influencing later genres of music. Same could be said for rock music, it was viewed as culturally revolutionary, hell Elvis Presley was viewed as indecent. Rock wasn’t accepted by “establish norms of music” either. Many people thought it lacked composition and was just noise. yet it had a massive cultural impact. The norms of music constantly change, there is no standard norm of music. Anything that uses melody, rhyme, and composition, that invokes emotion of some kind, is music. Or can be music. Yes, rap is music.

I'll skip the pleasantries, if you don't mind. Frankly, I was expecting a much more reasonable shortlist of reasons as to why you believe it isn't music but there are two immediate issues I can see here: You're free to believe hip-hop isn't music but it /is/. It's an established one at that with more than 25-30 years of unique history and progression to support the immutable fact that it is indeed music.Rap isn't so much a genre as it is an element of hip-hop. Hip-hop music can be instrumental as well. Rapping is something that one does. It's a verb, primarily. I'll expand on this later.Now then... addressing each of your points one-by-one: (They talk instead of sing) This is of no consequence. If you consider the genre of punk, there were a lot of vocalists that didn't sing in the traditional sense at all and a popular example of this is Sex Pistols' God Save The Queen. Hardly any singing throughout the track, is there?Didn't stop punk from being established as a subgenre of rock, did it? Thought so.(They don't even speak properly) As pointed out in one of the answers before mine, African American Vernacular English (or AAVE) is a dialect within English. Usually when someone says "Speak properly!" to black people, it comes equipped with a distinctive history of bigotry behind it. In other words, it is a demand to black people to be more like the majority racial demographic (in this case: Caucasians) rather than you taking a step outside of your comfort zone to learn something new about a culture you are ignorant about.  Contrary to popular belief, ignorance is quite a natural thing because no one can know everything otherwise there'd be no point in learning anything. However, when someone such as yourself parrots the already unfounded "points" as a reason to reject a rather valuable cultural offering like hip-hop, you end up appearing wilfully ignorant and coming off as rather obtuse.  Remember: everything has history, including your "points" detailed above.(There is no melody) I don't think melody was an issue when music first came about in the form of chanting and when melody was first introduced in the form of polyphony, there was a bit of a resistance to embracing it because of the then-established traditional norms. However, things progress and things change and old ways can be reinvented into creating new things. Hip-hop absolutely thrives on this principle, especially when you consider the sociopolitical climate that the genre was spawned in. More on that later.(They use 3rd grade rhyming schemes) "They" is a bit broad. Be more specific. There are countless emcees (also called rappers) that have proven to be some of the most skillful wordsmiths known to humankind. If you don't know any of them, then that'd be your own fault for not knowing more about the genre you're criticising here.  That said, sometimes complexity isn't necessary when making a good/great track and this kind of approach isn't exclusive to hip-hop. Consider any subgenre of rock, (yes, even technical metal) pop, or even country-western. You needn't always go over the top to make an impressive tune or showcase your musical ability... unless your main intention is one-upping your peers.  Speaking as a musician, there are plenty of people who do but that isn't always akin to making good art. It's more of a cliché.(They use words to rhyme but not that complete a thought) This "point" is probably the biggest indication that you aren't listening to hip-hop with the intent to learn.  Like many poets, there doesn't always need to be a complete thought in order to express oneself on the mic.  Sometimes, imagery is all that's needed. Again, this concept isn't exclusive to hip-hop so I'm quite baffled that you'd use this as a specific criticism.(The "music" is on an 8 second loop) Another example where rock comes to the fore as an example of where this never mattered, nor did it hinder rock's rise to prominence in music.  Lots of bands play variations of the same chords and riffs from not only other tracks they've created but tracks other bands have created.  Nirvana's Smells Like Teen Spirit is an awesome song and the most recognisable bit is the riff which is effectively repeated over and over ("Here we are now... entertainers!").(They don't even play the instruments) Again, depends on who "they" is. Emcees don't usually produce tracks and producers don't usually rap but there are some whom are multi-skilled and therefore do.  One of the greatest bands in history is a hip-hop band called The Roots. All of the instrumentation is live.  If you're criticising hip-hop for not always having live instrumentation then you'll need to extend that criticism to pop, all of electronic music (dance, house, trance et al), and anyone who performs a capella.Moral of the story: you either haven't thought this through or you're asking this question just for the sake of garnering some attention to this thread.  If it's the latter, you've succeeded. Well done. I hope you learned something.

In English-based culture - ABSOLUTELY. I lived in Russia for the first 30 years of my life. Russian culture had a whole movement of “singing poets”, with Vladimir Vysotsky - Wikipedia perhaps the most known. One of them, possibly second most known, Bulat Okudzhava - Wikipedia, was rather categorical on the terminology - “it is not music, it is a way of performing your poetry”. It doesn’t mean they had no melody and no guitar accompaniment. They were about as musical as early Bob Dylan. If Dylan was singing in Russian in USSR, he would be considered a singing poet rather than a musician. A combination of powerful, meaningful, deep rhyme and rather basic melody with mediocre vocal would be classified according to the strongest element. Would Dylan be interesting if his melodies and vocal were combined with Ariana Grande’s grade lyrics? Unlikely. Would his lyrics be worthwhile without any melody? The Nobel Prize Committee definitely thought so. So where it leaves Rap? Well, I cannot imagine a culture where Kanye West (musician) is not a musician. However if say Eminem was singing in Russian in 1960s-1980s USSR, he would be unquestionably seen as a poet influenced by Vladimir Mayakovsky - Wikipedia, rather than a musician. What I am trying to say, what qualify as music is culture-specific. Which gives us an easy answer - in English-speaking world, Rap is called music, and therefor is music.

Singing is really just dragging out syllables in cool ways. Rapping is very similar in how it sometimes drags out, twists, and alters syllables, all while still clearly saying each word correctly. Does rap count as music? Does hip hop count as music? I had to take a few minutes just to let the question sink in and make sure I wasn’t being trolled! Seriously though yes, it most certainly does count as music, well in my opinion anyway. Over the last 30 years I’ve listened to different styles of music alongside hip hop and they have all died along the way except rap music. I live in England so in the early 90’s my mates and I fell in love with the rave scene, that was the main music we were bumping but we still had time for N.W.A. The grunge scene erupted around the same time but burnt out very quickly. Mid 1990’s was all about bands like Oasis (collectively called Brit-pop but I hate that word). We listened to plenty of English bands but still had Biggie or Tupac on, then as the 90’s drew to a close the one and only Eminem appeared. This was around the time I just started listening to rap music and nothing else. Since the 1990’s ended there hasn’t really been any big movements musically, I don’t think pop punk or emo were big enough but there was rap music still going strong and outliving some of the greatest and biggest scenes ever in the industry. To the untrained ear it might sound like some guy or girl just talking over a beat, with some piano and maybe strings thrown in. Sometimes the music might sound a little bit daft (The Real Slim Shady can sound a bit ridiculous and I have had to defend it to friends that are stuck in the past). However people that are into rap music know how much love and work goes into making the beat, the piano, strings, any samples, scratching etc. And then there are the lyricists, wordsmiths whose brain seems to work on a different level to the rest of us if they have mastered their craft. Not only do they have to rap in time to the beat, it has to rhyme and say something you wanna hear. Then there are those that take it further, I’m gonna use Eminem for this example. Simply put he can make 2 or 3 words at the end of each line rhyme instead of just 1 syllable that some use as it is easier. Not just that but Eminem tries to get words from earlier on in the sentence to rhyme. That’s why he’s the best, but I only used him as an example, other talented rappers can do it too. To the uninitiated it might sound simple to make a rap track but it is a real labour of love and a real craft. People have mocked me for listening to it and I just say “You try it. Come on write a few bars now” and if they do they realise it’s a lot harder than they expected. So, does rap count as music? You’re damn right it does. A style that seems easy to outsiders to is very deceiving. A style that has outlived many other musical movements and scenes. A style that should definitely count as music (except mumble rap, keep that away from me lol). Take care everyone

A common fallacy in argument is to try to win by definition instead of by real argument.  If you said "I think rap is not good music" or "...not interesting as music" you could defend that far more easily than by saying "it isn't music." It would also be more likely to spare you charges of racism/classism. And suppose it isn't music? A Rembrandt isn't music either. The movie "Gravity" isn't music, but music is part of it. A wind chime isn't musical but it sounds nice. And it isn't poetry, or product design either. Categories are necessary and convenient, but if you lean on them too heavily they become a straitjacket that separates you from really experiencing life.  Thus many rap songs combine elements of rap with elements of conventional song. Hard to say "This part is music and that part isn't." George Anthiel's "Ballet Mechanic" employed a symphony orchestra and an aircraft engine. Tchaikovsky's 1812 overture includes cannon fire. Is it then to be classified as "not music" ?  A guy I once knew from an Arabic culture told me Western music wasn't music because the notes were so far apart they didn't sound like melodies to him (Arabic music is highly melismatic). An Indian classical musician I once knew said Western music sounded primitive to her because its rhythms were so childish.  I'm a sophisticated listener. My favorite music is J.S. Bach's later works (Goldberg Variations, Musical Offering, Die Kunst der Fuge), which are some of the most austere, cerebral yet spiritual music ever composed. And I'm familiar with most genres, around the world and through the ages. And I don't like most rap--especially the raps that are mostly crude braggadoccio.  But I've also found that the best music in genres I don't generally like is still worth listening to. Conversely, though I'm an opera lover, I don't enjoy probably the majority of operas--tedious piffle.  With rap, there are some works that I've found genuinely moving, such as Kanye West's "Jesus walks" :   And yes, I know what a jerkwad Kanye West can be. So was Wagner. Or Lauryn Hill's Everything is Everything:  ......which mixes song and rap. Or the intensely moral fable by Eminem and Dr. Dre, "Guilty conscience" :  ...which has no "real singing," is often vulgar/obscene...yet which is a real work of art--and could make the world a better place if every thoughtless youth would take it to heart. It's a big world.

Of course. It’s different than “contemporary” music, but so was rock and roll before it became popular. If you lived through the second World War, then you remember rock rising in popularity in the ‘50s, until it had all but drowned out classical music in the youth (baby-boomer) population, much to the dismay of the adults who had grown up on “the classics.” Led Zeppelin scared the hell out of people who had listened to Sinatra their whole lives. Rock also came to be associated with the hippie/psychedelia movement. Flash forward 20–30 years, to the early ‘90s. A new type of music was being created, much different from the “classics” our parents grew up with, and the “classics” their parents had. This time, it was hip-hop, and due to it’s introducers being in the “gang scene”, this is what it became equated with. Now every kid who listens to rap wants to drink lean, gangbang, and kill people. Right?! Flash forward another 20 years. Those kids who grew up on hip-hop have kids, and the new kids are listening to dubstep. It’s so much different, with only electronic noises, and it’s introducers did coke and molly at lightshows. Now, every kid who listens to dubstep wants to be deadmau5 and do drugs with a big mickey mouse thing on his head, right?! Times change, and music changes. Just because you don’t like a particular music, doesn’t mean it isn’t music. It just means you’re too ignorant to enjoy an art form you are unfamiliar with. Stick to your “classic” Pink Floyd records, Grampy will stick to his “classic” Sinatra collection, your son will stick to his “classic” Tupac Shakur CD’s, and in a few years your grandson will have an iPhone loaded with “classic” dubstep singles, and everyone will be happy and enjoy their own music.

Wow… A lot of dissension here… I guess I’ll chime in too… Love it, hate it or be totally ambivalent about it, Rap IS music. - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - Jazz is music. Blues is music. Rock is music. Drum circles are music. - - - - - - - - - - - - - The drum solo of “In-A-Gadda-Da-Vida” is music. - Hell… A beatnik reading poetry over bongos playing is even music. What qualifies? Any artistic use of sound to engage the listener. It doesn’t need to have lyrics. It doesn’t need to have melody. It doesn’t even need to have a predictable pulse. It just has to be sonic, take up some time, and elicit a response. Judging by the extreme strong feelings I’m seeing in these posts, Rap is possibly the most virulent form of music to ever exist! Do I like Rap? Not particularly for the most part. However, there are some things like “Heavy Mental” by Killah Priest that I find absolutely brilliant! And a lot of music by Gorillaz (if you can call that Rap, some isn’t quite Rap…) is enchanting. On the other hand (completely different side of the musical spectrum) I find music written by Chopin to be forced and disjointed… often lacking in a smooth metered pulse. - It just leaves me cold. - I rather prefer Mozart, Tchaikovsky, and to a lesser extent, Bach and Wagner. - However, there are literally millions of Classical music enthusiasts that truly love Chopin. I’m just not one of them. Bear in mind that typically, I like rock (term used broadly)… - Albums by Cream, Santana, Led Zeppelin, Hendrix, Deep Purple, early Black Sabbath, Creedence Clearwater Revival, Soundgarden, Clutch, Modest Mouse, Tool, and quite a few singles by many others. - I also like Ragtime, 1920s Jazz and a great deal of Fusion Jazz, but not 1950s Jazz at all. - I like quite a lot of Bluegrass and really old country like Hank Williams Sr. (but not Jr. at all, and not much new country either). And I like quite a lot of the 1960s Motown songs. And some classical. But not modern pop. Anyway, most would say my taste in music is pretty diverse. I once knew a professional pianist (and this guy loved Chopin!) who had project with an ensemble that did some extremely experimental music. Bicycle wheels tuned to melodies and spun while a guitar pick was held against the spokes. Trumpets played into a bucket of water. Compositions where everyone was in a different key and time signature. Some was quite appealing, but some was just totally lost on me. However there was this one piece another pianist did… It was literally ONE NOTE! And occasionally also a higher or lower octave of that note. It began slowly with a gentle repetition of the note. There would be pauses… Then stronger hits of the note… Then much stronger. It went up and down in dynamics for a while, then it wound down and finally ended. ONE NOTE! - When it first began, I thought the pianist was joking, pulling some sort of avant garde nonsense. But by the end I was mesmerized! The feeling it left me with was one of great release and hopefulness. ONE NOTE! But it had the ability to touch ones’ soul. Regardless of how minimal it was, it was truly music.

In my opinion, it counts as “music” because it contains the most basic, primitive elements that define music. There’s rarely an actual melody, and chanting doesn’t count as “singing”. But it keeps a steady beat, which is a defining attribute of music. Typically we think of music. as composed by a musician, for specific musical instruments arranged in a cohesive, flowing medley of sound. Rap doesn’t meet this standard, as quite a bit is merely someone shouting or muttering crude, unsophisticated pseudorhymes without literary merit or the complexity required to convey subtlety and nuanced emotion. Furthermore, it is frequently based upon sampling and re-sampling the work of genuine musicians. Musician, of course, defined as “a professional who has studied the art of, and acquired a demonstrable mastery of one or more standard performative musical instruments.” However, the fact that it maintains an identifiable and steady beat, accompanied by some form of personal expression, however crude, vulgar and poorly articulated, does indeed allow it a dubious, yet valid claim as “music”.

Actually this is absolutely and demonstrably wrong. The very first music was made by someone beating a drum while telling a story. In this sense rap is the truest form of music there is. Even traveling minstrels in old Europe rarely sang because they couldn't. ‘Modern’ norms even accept it as music. Those who do not subscribe to a strict European perspective of music that even Europeans reject. In fact, classical music is a homogenized, simplified version of all the other music of the world. Very few musical systems are limited to just 12 notes and if you calculate the cycle of fifths properly you find that it is infinite and never ends on an octave. You don't even have to calculate it in fact. The fifth is 2/3 the frequency of the root, the octave is 1/2. There is no mathematical way to turn 2/3 into a number that matches 1/2. So Westerners said ‘Forget this, it's too hard. Let's make it 12 notes and end on an octave’. That being said, rap is music and so is classical composer John Cage’s ‘4 minutes and 33 seconds of silence for any instrument’.

From a technical point of view, rap is “music”. Now, music, as is beauty, is in the ear or eye of the beholder. As a white person, I am probably not the best judge of what young people think of as music, but from my vantage point, rap is only music “technically”. Are “rappers” musical? No. They recite (not sing) the words that are written for them by producers; in much the same way that musical singers do. The difference is that musical performers have talent. Modern day rap is just as much a factory production as other forms of pop music. Other people have mentioned how varied and smart the rap producers are for stealing bits and pieces of other more successful works and recombining them into a mosh mash of discordant noises. I am not talented in music production, but sometimes I feel I could do better. Is rap music? Technically, yes. In reality, most often the answer is no. To group violent, misogynistic “gangsta” words that are poorly recited to the beat of other peoples music with actual music is to sound the death knell of what “music” actually is.

Rap itself, rhythmically spoken words, does not count as music in my book. I’d suggest that it doesn’t count as music in most people’s books. But most rap music isn’t just spoken words. It’s music with words rhythmically spoken over it. So it is objectively “music”. When people say it isn’t music, they’re only trying to delineate some form of music that they happen to like as being “real music”, and other music as “not music”. Which frankly, is a form of snobbish self-deceit. It’s like saying that burgers are “not food”. What the blazes are they then? Plasma? Mineral formations? Animals that happen to have randomly died due to suffocating between two pieces of bread? Some people are into this kind of half-joking snobbishness. I just find it irritating, since it can make having a meaningful conversation on the topic almost impossible.

Short answer: Duh. Of course rap is music! You ask: WHY? We'd have to go back almost four hundred years in the study of Western Musicology, and I CAN DO THAT FOR YOU/WITH YOU (I literally went to school for this), but something tells me that's not what you’re going for. We'll go back go the early 1900’s instead, in France, Louisiana, and the night clubs of Harlem. In France, a couple of weird dudes were experimenting with early audio recording technology and were asking questions you clearly never thought to ask but that Patrick Star of SpongeBob might have sooner asked: “Is a train whistle an instrument? Is Mayonnaise an instrument?” To prove this, they recorded a loop of a train whistle, and dubbed it to be the earliest form of electronic music, called “Musique Concrête” or “Concrete Music” due to lacking a distinct rhythm or any prior professed “attributes of music”, since the sound didn't come from a traditional musical instrument, but from a mode of transportation.  If you take umbrage with this classification for instruments, you take umbrage with classic Americana pop song “The Leader of the Pack” by the Shangri-La's, which features the revving of a motorcycle as a percussive element in the chorus.  Meanwhile, in Louisiana, Dixie music and Ragtime were being formed by black American musicians around the same time as those two weird white dudes in France, basing their instrumentation on a combination of classical era rules of composition, with additional syncopation that was less noted in classical music than in rag time.   A few years after, based on slave songs in the south as they travelled north to take on new life in the north and south, gospel music was born on the east coast, country and bluegrass music to the south, and 12 Bar blues to the north in the club of Harlem.  Hey, doesn't this sound like that one song?  No, the other one…  Wait, they're all… The same? Yes, that's the idea of the 12 bar blues: it's a very specific, easily calculated formula based on note lengths, note pitches descending in succession, before jumping high, then to a middle range before going back to the bass notes, in a very specific, easily tracked way over 12 measures. By the 1950’s, this music would evolve to Big Band and the progenitors of swing based loosely on the origins of gospel singers and the 12 bar blues.  The one thing uniting all of these musicians besides the fact that they were all black Americans, is that the polyrhythms commonly expressed in the melodies and rhythms is highly complex and is a staple of distinctly African music (I learned that one in ETHNOmusicology, I cannot anymore highly recommend you take BOTH courses if you can: SO informational!). Whether in the Caribbean, the heart of Africa, or the heartland of the U.S.A, black musicians have intuitively participated in a beautiful, musical heritage, tradition, and inheritance, and pushed this tradition along to the modern day. (Phew!, Now let's look directly at rap!) Listen to any rap or hip-hop based song. Tap out the rhythm for the supporting drum line with one hand while tapping out the vocal rhythm with another, and tap your foot to the tempo of the song.  I haven't asked you to do anything impossible: professional Drummers manage this tiny miracle feat of the human body every day they work. Look at how different every rhythmic section is from each other. These are the remnants of the African polyrhythms that have followed black musicians and their families across centuries and oceans. MIMS does the audience a lovely favor here by clapping the tempo directly for our less knowledgeable listeners, giving us a template to follow. The clap is likely a sound effect, the concept borrowed from those crazy French dudes almost sixty years earlier, utilized in a rhythmic way as a helpful percussive element to ground the listener and give them a foundation they can relate to. Now, observe the digital backing melodic ostinato in the background. The electronic instrument has a pure, almost whispered timbre like a soprano voice gently hooting in the background. The melody of the ostinato starts on one note for three even quarter note counts, raises to another pitch playing for three quarter notes counts, lowers to a different pitch for three quarter notes, before lifting high for six equally even quarter note counts for six counts. Fellow sound engineer Adam Neely recently detailed the ostinato of this song in a video commenting on the truly atrocious verdict against Katy Perry's Dark Horse recently. You can start at 5:28 in his video and he'll briefly bring it up shortly after.  That being said…. This is just one example of a rap song that has engaged in a rich music tradition spanning centuries, and innovations spanning almost a hundred years, back to the time of 20th century art music and rag time. The complex use of polyrhythms, the syncopation, the melodic complexity! You know what I'll argue was NOT music? These awful covers by this church choir!

Very few, next to zero, rappers write their music. It is appropriated for them, written for them, or sampled by them, but rarely ever comprehended for it's technical qualities. There are exceptions. Bone, Rhazelle, Kanye and others cross over from merely chanting or speaking, and choose what tones to produce or which should carry their message. Rap alone, however, is not music, anymore than an auctioneer calling cadence is music. It may have musical qualities, but it is not music (usually). That being said, rap songs ARE music, and that matters little, since it's popularity has, in recent times, eclipsed all other forms of song in popularity. Rap is changing the world In a further aside, it is easy to remember how the spell rhythm wigh the acronym; Rap Has Yet To Help Millions.

I’m not a huge rap or hip-hop fan. But I’m glad they’re out there. One of the reasons rap came about was because that under President Reagan’s leadership public school funding was cut drastically. One of the first things to go was music classes in those schools. Inner-city youth had no access to guitars or saxophones, drums or pianos. So they used the tools they had: Turntables and voices. I think there’s something beautiful about that. Kids found a way to express themselves artistically, they refused to be put down. That’s called resilience. And they sang about what they knew, the things that were happening around them. What else were they supposed to sing about? Rap is music. If you can’t hear it as music then you don’t understand what the word music means. You’ve decided that a particular art form must adhere to your preconceived notions of what that art form is. But all art forms must have the freedom to grow or they die. There’s room for all kinds of growth, you just have to allow it some space. And the space is there.

Yes. Just like throat singing and Gregorian chanting is music. Just because you don’t utilize every aspect of music theory doesn’t mean that what you’re doing isn’t music. Some artists use melody over rhythm. Some use harmony over melody. Some use rhythm over either of the two. Rappers dominantly rely on rhythm for their music. Of course there is often some sort of chord structure or melody line that accompanies it; but it’s not typically the dominant theme. The words, the flow, the rhythm is what makes rap music what it is. Speaking to a rhythm. There needn’t be a melody or a chord structure at all sometimes. Often the rhythm is all you need to be moved or inspired. Many ancient cultures utilized rhythmic structures long before incorporating melody or harmony into their music. Rap speaks to that. It’s visceral, grounded, human. Then there are the words. The spoken word can quite easily be defined as music. There is a lilting nuance to everyone’s voice that is unique. Rappers tap into this form of expression and push it farther; sometimes to the extreme. The vocal phrasing and linguistic rhyming is often far more brilliant in rap music than in any pop or rock lyrics. When it’s the dominant driving factor, you’re going to focus on it more and therefore get better at it. The expressive force of rhythm and the technical aspects of linguistic communication come together to comprise the bulk of rap music. Sure, there are many rappers who are quite adept at using chord structures and motifs and melodies just like there are many rock/pop artists who are quite adept at using rhythms and complex rhyme schemes. Music has no hard line boundaries when it comes to the artist’s expression. But one thing’s for sure: Rap is definitely music.

We have rap music. We’ve been churning them out for hundreds of years. “Rapping” means chanting. We had our gušle songs. I suppose it’s a form of music that will develop when you have a whole lot to say, more than might fit into the form of lyrics. We definitely had a lot to say. This was during the Turkish, Ottoman occupation of Serbia. We woke up one day to find ourselves kidnapped into the Middle East. Christians kidnapped into the Middle East. Not propitious. Of course, we hadn’t gone anywhere, the borders had just shifted and there we were. Marooned within a harsh jurisprudence which did not allow us to testify against them in court. In other words, we had no rights they were bound to respect. This went on for 530 years. It is said that in the late 19th century the average British farmer, who was literate, knew considerably LESS about his own country’s history than the average Serbian peasant knew about his, even though the illiteracy rate for us was about 95%. That was because of these songs. Chanted songs. Rap songs. They were so good that there were English scholars who went to the considerable trouble of learning our language just to be able to read the songs. They run the gamut from tragic to tragicomic, to playful, to sardonic. Generally, the sense of humor is on the wicked side. Most often they are intensely political, involving a defiant social commentary. A collection in English is available, compiled by a Chapel Hill professor, Vasa Mihailovich. Amazon.com: Songs of the Serbian People: From the Collections of Vuk Karadzic (Russian and East European Studies) (9780822956099): Milne Holton, Vasa D. Mihailovich: Books  He presents one of the last songs about Prince Marko. Marko started out as a superhero soldier who could kill 10,000 enemies in a day, all by himself. In this last one, he’s nothing more than a sharecropper whose mother is nagging him to get to work plowing, so he goes out and plows the road. The subtext is that while on the land one is sharecropping, there are a few prohibitions about being assaulted. On the road, however, it’s a road warrior environment where any Turk, or any Moslem for that matter, can do whatever they want, without censure, to any Christian Serb, who is to get out of the road, hat in hand and allow the real citizen to pass, hoping not to end up in a willow tree. Srbe na vrbe.  So, that’s why Marko is plowing the road, turning it into his own turf wherein he has some rights. If this “rapping” doesn’t qualify as music, what is it? I guess it’s merely a profoundly powerful art form. And don’t forget, the original Christian services, as in the Christian Orthodox liturgy, are also chanted. Christianity grew for 1500 years, without any sort of literate body of believers, by way of . . . rapping.
