Because it is music. I understand what you mean: it isn’t totally my favorite genre either, but it really still is music. Here’s why: All music, on the entire planet, only consists of 3 elements: MelodyHarmonyRhythm.It is the interplay of these elements, that creates all the different genres. For example, if you make the rhythm bouncy (swinging), and you make the harmony complex adding tensions to the chords, you will invariably end up with something jazzy. If you use simple short melody lines that keep repeating, make the harmony very simple only consisting of 1 repetitive chord for example, then you have to make the rhythm busier or more interesting for it not to be boring… et voila: you have funk music or something that will come closer to having a funk or dance music feel. So music is this constant balancing act between these 3 elements. If the song is at a fast tempo (rhythm), you don’t want a whole lot of chords. If the song is rhythmically really busy, you don’t want a busy harmonic rhythm (the pace at which chords change). If the song had really complex, rich sounding chords, then you don’t want a ton of them happening really fast after one another or you don’t want a busy rhythm. At faster or busier rhyhms, you don’t want really intricate, busy melodies. And so on and so on. So in hip hop: there is less melody, because the melody is taken over by the rapping. The rapping serves 2 things: it tells the story, ANDit provides a rhythm, as the rapper delivers he lyrics with a certain rhythmic flow and delivery that is unique to that rapper. Tupac for example, has an entirely different rhythmic flow than Eminem, who both have a very different flow from Snoop.The harmony is usually repetitive and not too complex. The reason for this is that doing otherwise, would distract from the usually busy wording, and the rhythmic flow of the rap. The rhythm(s) provided by the percussion/drums etc are interesting and layered, very often integrating various loops in the beat. So because of all that, yes it is definitely music. :)

ORIGINAL QUESTION: Does rap count as music? From a local rap “star” in a major city some 40 years ago, I can say definitively, rap is not music. Why? It lacks “melody” the single defining characteristic of music. That’s not a rap against rap though. Dance isn’t music either. But we don’t look down upon dance because it’s not music. Dance is done TO music. Rap is done TO music. They are both admirable art-forms in their own right. They’re just not music. It’s by no means a put-down. It’s just an observation. Music has certain characteristics. The most defining of which is melody. Rap, by definition, has no melody. Rap is poetry. Rap is done TO music. It isn’t music. Dance is done TO music. It isn’t music.

As frustrating as this question is, before I say anything else, I absolutely must answer: YES—rap “counts” as music. Look up any definition of the word “music” and I guarantee it says something like “rhythmic organization of sound.” Actually, wait—I’ll just look it up for you. Here are screenshots from what I just Googled:  (via What is Music? - Definition, Terminology & Characteristics | Study.com)  (via What Is Music…Exactly?)  (via Definition of MUSIC)  Okay so none of them exactly said “rhythmic organization of sound” but they all basically did. And if you don’t believe me then go look it up for yourself. By definition, rap absolutely “counts” as music. It has to count as music. It literally cannot be considered not music. Actually, I’m willing to say that rap, more than any other genre, not only “counts” as music, but actually epitomizes the definition of music through it’s emphasis on repetitive sound patterns. Yes: I think rap is the most music-y of all music. Think about it: we’ve clearly identified that music is defined by patterns of sound and that’s what makes it so attractive to us. It’s an innate human reaction to repeated vibrations. We subconsciously obsess over predictable patterns and for the most part, that’s what music is. Of course, there are plenty of genres (like Jazz or Heavy Metal) that don’t have a ton of repeating sound combinations—which kind of explains why those aren’t the most popular genres of music—but are still considered music (and some pretty great music at that). Rap, though, is typically the genre with the most rhythmic patterns—both instrumentally and vocally (and not by coincidence, either). That’s probably why it’s the most popular music in the world right now. Let’s use Kendrick Lamar’s “M.A.A.D. City” as an example of a rap song that prioritize instrumental and vocal sound patterns. Here is the musical composition of the famous 2012 track off of his sophomore album g.o.o.d kid, M.A.A.D City:  Just looking at it, what do you notice? You don’t have to be able to read music to see the constant repetitiveness throughout the entirety of the first hook and verse (and the rest of the song is structured the same way). This sort of instrumental repetitiveness simply does not occur at the same frequency in other genres of music. But to take it a step further and consider vocal patterns, let’s look at the lyrics:  (courtesy of Genius.com) Read the first bar out loud (the first four lines of the verse). It’s a simple AAAA end-rhyme scheme, but listening to yourself say it aloud, what else did you hear? Looking more closely, there are a number of other rhymes within each line to further enhance a rhythmic pattern. Aside from lane, cocaine, pain, and brain all rhyming, Lamar rhymes rap, crack, cul-de-sac, and Cognac together, while managing to squeeze in the rhyming “ay” sound with major and weighin’. Considering the simple fact that this verse is 32 bars long, and that Lamar keeps up (and actually increases) his pattern of rhyming throughout the rest of the tract—all the while matching the instrumental pattern of the beat with his voice—it becomes pretty clear that rap not only is an organization of sound patterns exemplifies musical patterns. Of course no one rap song is the same as the next. And there are plenty of rap songs that have far less instrumental and vocal patterns than Lamar’s M.A.A.D. City. Still, the vast majority of rap songs have more organized and repetitive sound patterns than any other form of music—inherently making it, by definition, the most music-like form genre compared to any other genre of music. Those norms are largely bullshit. No, really! There is no one universally accepted definition of music. For instance: Gregorian chants are monophonic, thus they lack harmony and lack any form of accompaniment to the main melody. Percussive pieces lack both harmony and melody. The idea of music being a form of self-expression on the composer’s part wasn’t really a thing before the Romantic period. The idea of music being primarily an aesthetic phenomenon is inexistent in contexts such as ritualistic or ceremonial music. Unwanted music can rapidly devolve into noise, and pieces like John Cage’s 4:33 are intended to make the listener perceive ambient sounds as music. The idea of rap not being music is sort of this conservative meme. It has no real basis in music studies, and is just an attempt to frame dislike, which is a subjective thing, into some sort of fake objective concept. Also, outside the oft-hated microverses of gangsta rap and booty rap there is a wealth of excellent music. For instance, try listening to anything that has Nujabes’s name on it.

Lots of ink is being spilled in answers that have good points but that do not disclose the linguistic groundings of the question. If shows how much unnecessary controversy can be created when questions are dropped without elaboration. First, the poster did not clarify if they want the answer to be based on some official definition of music or based on connotations around “music”. Without that clarification, different posters are inevitably going to “latch” onto different elements of language and argue into infinity. Second, establishing borders around definitions (in this case “music”) often seems to be a debate about good and bad (is rap music “legitimate”). But I hope the poster is not expecting the definitions of words to be insight into the reality which his question reflects. Third, if one considers the writing of Wittgenstein, most words carry a family of meanings. Consider the many meanings of the word “game”. One implication of this is that the meanings of words (“music”) is only with great strife settled by emotional argument. Forth, I do not assume that the poster is being racially narrow in the question. I hope those who answer the question can see that the question can stand as legitimate in and of itself. However, I hope the poster is aware of the potential racial undertones of the question in light of history. Music is high value and even almost sacred in many elements of culture.

There have been a lot of great answers to this question that go into exceptional and convincing detail. There is only one thing that I can add without being redundant. They are still sounds, just like the 8-second loop of music that is not actually played by a human, and can be organized and synergized with other elements and sounds to create a whole, which is unquestionably and quantifiably a piece of music. Whether one can appreciate it is another matter entirely, but that does not subtract from its intrinsically musical qualities.

Questions of the form "Is item X really in category Y?", where "category Y" is not strictly defined, are all fundamentally flawed, because the question just becomes an argument about the definition of Y. Words are just pointers to concepts in people's minds, and any given word has a different definition for every person who hears it. When you say the word "snow" to a Alaskan, what pops into their head is very different than the same word spoken to a Floridian, so the sentence "Do you enjoy snow?" is actually two different questions when asked to the two different people. So when you ask "Does rap count as music," you're only inviting a unconstructive and unwinnable argument over the One True Definition of a conceptually overloaded word.
